"There's a lot to be said for making people laugh... It isn't much, but it's better than nothing in this cockeyed caravan."  

What a classic!  Preston Sturges' masterpiece delights and insights.  Equal parts humor and meloncholy, it's almost Shakespearean in scope.  The screenplay is as good as it gets, and Joel McCrea is terrific.  Veronica Lake ain't no slouch either.  One of my new favorites!
I watched this ten days ago and I hardly remember anything about it. That's not a good sign. I do remember not finding it funny or that interesting.

Sullivan's Travels is a film about a big Hollywood comedy director who wants to make a more substantive work about the hardships of the common man. The only problem? He doesn't know anything about them. There were one or two scenes of real power here; it's a bit broad in places and could be funnier/punchier but it's worth seeing.
Laughter, A Precious Commodity In This Cockeyed Caravan--Fails bitterly at both comedy and tragedy!!

A wealthy hollywood director gets more than he bargained for when he goes out looking for "trouble" so as to better identify with the common man (and make a better film dramatizing their plight).  The director's name is Sullivan (Joel McCrea), and he is more known for goofy slapstick than dramatic human interest.  He believes himself to be a noble pursuer of truth and justice, but as his butler Burrows points out, dressing up as a bum and hoboing around is something "only the morbid rich would find glamorous".  At first, the studio is intent on following him around (in a giant bus, no less) to document this adventure, but he quickly loses them after making a deal to meet up with them later.  Not long after, he's taken in by a girl (Veronica Lake) who buys him a ham-and-egg breakfast as she's on her way east, back home.  Sullivan is attracted to her and wants to make a movie with her, only he's still trying to maintain his incognito status, so as a compromise, he goes home and steals his own car so as to give her a ride to whereever she wants to go ("Chicago", she says).  After she discovers his ruse, the girl decides to go along with him on his adventure ("How can I be alone if you're with me?" he asks, but to no avail), and the two delve right into the seedy underbelly of America's misfortunes.  Riding the rails, sleeping in flophouses, looking for handouts, as if some great and noble purpose could be distilled from abject misery.  But as with other martyrs, that nobility is never pure, as they could escape their condition at anytime they so choose, he's never really down and out, he still has his millions waiting for him at home, and so the deception is never fully realized as he knows who he is.  Ah, but after he goes back to being Sullivan, and he's clunked over the head and robbed by a hobo and then thrown onto a freight train, well only then does he come to realize the nature of being lowly and without friends.  Sullivan comes to realize the irony of socially conscious films is that they do nothing for the people they purport to defend, that watching a film doesn't change anyone's plight.  The best a film can hope to do for the lowest rungs of our society is take away the burden of life for a little while, take a person somewhere they've never been before, let them laugh and enjoy themselves, even if it's just for a little while.  Throwing their poverty back up in their faces doesn't help them, not even a little bit.
Be careful what you wish for...
Hilarious and charming. Everyone who has ever loved movies owes it to themselves to watch this. It's a rollicking, side splitting and passionate gem.

Was very good for the first hour (with a memorable chase scene and ridiculous lines of dialogue) but then for the last half hour took a turn from being a comedy to a serious drama and wasn't enjoyable to see that turn.

Why can't they make movies like they used to!? Sullivan's Travels is an absolute gem of a movie and given the year it was made it still holds up. Absolutely hilarious, the scene where the bus starts chasing the car my God it felt like my sides were gonna split! And great commentary on the movie business from within the movie business. Definitely one to watch!

Starring Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake, with director Preston Sturges, Sullivan's Travels is about a highly successful film director (McCrea) who wants to make a movie about the common man and suffering. However, he usually writes comedies and so he decides to go on the road as a hobo to try and understand the lifestyle. During his adventures he meets a young failed actress (Lake) who is about to leave Hollywood. Wanting to help her, Sully tells the girl what he is doing and they go off together masquerading as tramps. After taking a short respite, he goes on the road again, this time alone. Through a series of events he finds himself in a chain gang while his friends assume he is dead. Eventually he is freed but not before learning a valuable lesson. If he wants to relate with the poor he should give them laughter instead of hardship. I found this movie to be an enjoyable  light comedy (even though I had never heard of it beforehand).

love the main idea of this movie, and surprised finding out that Veronica Lake was actually 7-8 month pregnant during filming this movie, yet she 's able to hide it and delivered a good performance :)

Watched for the ongoing Movie Shame Monday project, and I have to say that so far Veronica Lake has been very good to me.  She was a real stunner, and appeared in a lot of interesting movies.  This time around she appears opposite Joel McCrea, who is a film producer who wants to get in touch with the real America, so he takes a road trip riding the rails, where he meets the hotness that is Veronica Lake.  

The film takes a strangely uncomfortable dark turn in the middle that I wasn't expecting, which sort of ham-strings my rating a bit, but it's still well worth a look.

Give it a rental.
A feel good comedy reminding us what's important in the day to day grind. 1001 movies to see before you die.
Wierd, wacky and sometimes sombre sturgess comedy has a great cast but a strange sense of humor
A brutally important film for anyone who wants to go into making movies.

Finally got to see this classic film. It was a wonderful take on the Hollywood film industry in the early 40s! And I can certainly see how Veronica Lake was the inspiration for Jessica Rabbit in Who Framed Roger Rabbit! Definitely worth seeing if you haven't already!

A movie about an A-list director doing research for a movie; It's a comedy, then a drama, then a comedy, with satire all over. Writer/director Preston Sturges tears off the hand that feeds, attacking an empty-headed and -hearted Hollywood with devastating satirical savagery, poking fun at their lame attempts to hide their disconnection from reality by releasing films about the less fortunate. Get the irony yet? Self-referential irony may have become less hip in the aftermath of countless pretenders, but the tongue-in-cheek dialogue, Veronica Lake and Joel McCrea more then holding their own as the charismatic leads, and the awkward anti-racist humor remain a genuine genre high point. It may lay on the message a little thick, and I feel like I'm being manipulated by the design cleverness, but I'm taken by this movie, despite my best cynical intentions.
Discovering Preston Sturges is a great achievement and an honor !!

Cinema /movies started as a mode of entertainment then transformed in education later on.Well I guess this was the phase when all of this was going on .this movie is a b'ful example of this .it's funny , emotional , it has drama , Henceforth a complete entertainer. Classic

What doesn't work at times doesn't really matter, because what works is incredibly brilliant and overall makes the film touching. Sullivan's a rich director who's always had money, but he's tired of making comedies. It's time to make a film about the poor. He needs to make something real, something worthwhile. The studio heads tell him that's impossible for him because he's never had to live as a poor man, so Sullivan decides to go on the streets dressed in old, torn up clothes and only ten cents. The first day he's followed by people from the studio because they want to make sure they don't lose their investment. He jumps in a crazy 13-year-old's car and they fly around, which causes everyone in the bus following him to have a rough time. After they're done he finally gets them to agree to stop following him. That day he works for a woman in her yard then goes out with her at night. He escapes in the middle of the night and jumps onto a truck, only to find himself back in Hollywood again. Sucks to be you, Sullivan. Poor guy can't even get away from his city. While back he meets the girl played by the stunning Veronica Lake. She has the perfect noir sense about her. She could have played every femme fatale and I would have been okay with it. Okay, that might be pushing it, but still you get my point. Anyway, she buys him food and he discovers she wants to be an actress, so in order to repay her he tells her who he truly is after they go to prison because the police think he stole his car. The story goes along, she becomes interested in him, doesn't want to just try to get into pictures, so she follows him on his adventures of being poor. They make up the girl to look like a boy just in case some guy gets any funny ideas. One night Sullivan gets his shoes stolen, which we know is a big deal because the soles of his shoes have his identification card in them. When Sullivan goes out to give poor people money at night he gets mugged and thrown in a train. The mugger gets ran over by a train while trying to pick up all the money he dropped. This turns out to be the guy who also stole his shoes. Since Sullivan's knocked out in a boxcar people believe that the dead body is his since the face is unidentifiable. Here's where the plot gets a little sloppy. Sullivan hits a railroad attendant for badgering him after he gets off the train and winds up in court. Here he doesn't remember his name or what happened. The blow on the head has left him with a bit of amnesia. Because of this he gets a shorter 6 year sentence to a workers camp. This is why even though it seems sloppily put together, it works. He finally gets to see what it's like to be poor and unfortunate. If he acts better he can get more privileges, but no matter what you're always seen as a lesser human being. That's why it's so heartfelt when they go to the black church and watch a movie there with everyone laughing. Sullivan learns what he was supposed to from the start: if he's going to make a movie about poor people he has to know how to do so. They don't want to see a sad film about poor people. They go to films to escape. And only the rich will watch movies about the poor to make themselves feel better. But here's the brilliance: Preston Sturges just made a movie sympathizing with poor people, showing their condition and unveiling some truths not a lot of people want to hear or see. In the end you get Sullivan finding out how to get out of the camp (telling people he's the one who killed Sullivan which gets his picture in the paper) and he finds out his wife is remarried and now he can be with the girl. Most importantly he understands that comedy pictures are worth more than he ever realized. The last shot of Sullivan and the girl mixed with the people laughing in the church almost brought a tear to my eye. Sullivan's Travels is a mostly overlooked film even though it's one of those scripts that overall so brilliant every filmmaker should be trying to learn from it, whether if it's for the message, dialogue, or comedy. This film just works so well.

From the brilliant mind of Preston Sturges, Sullivan's Travels resonates on many levels: as screwball comedy, Hollywood satire and Depression era drama. Plus, Veronica Lake has such a hypnotic screen presence.
Good movie with a great message .
Dry wit sums it up, but it's definitely movie that wants to make you think as well as make a statement about both the world and Hollywood in general.

A good example of Preston Sturges' trademark comedic wit and social commentary, but Veronica Lake's wannabe actress character, and her burgeoning relationship with McCrea's Sullivan, is kind of half-baked. You almost buy it, but it needs more than a scene of them pushing one another into a swimming pool to click.
How have I not seen this before today on TMC? :)

Preston Sturges uses an excellent and fresh cast in this amusing comedy classic, and I loved how he found a way to use a Disney short in the film (Playful Pluto). The movie does come off as being a bit pretentious though. (First and only viewing - 2/2/2014)

A wonderful film about showing one of the most precious gifts that any person can obtain for free which is laughter. However, the icing on the cake for this film are the performances of Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake, the hilarious comedy in the film, and the heart and soul it possesses in Sullivan's Travels.

This highly-regarded, classic film of a movie executive wanting to make a film showing the gritty, realism of Depression-era America needs to be watched in the context of the year it was released and compared against anything at the time.  Otherwise, it's importance and the respect it deserves is easily overlooked.  Upon the screen of a 2012 audience, the movie may seem average and so dated as to be misunderstood.  However, it is a dark comedy, one of the first of its kind, and should be noted for how gritty and honest it truly is, especially for 1941.  Since I've been watching a lot of classic films lately, it was easy to notice how the "language" and "attitude" of this film is definitely cutting-edge compared to its contemporaries.  John Sullivan applies the "method" manner of film development by taking on the persona of a homeless, every-day man in order to obtain the feel of how his audiences were dealing with real life.  Comedy and drama ensue, but eventually, he learns more than he bargained for.
A pretty enjoyable comedy about class that might be a little heavy on the montage at some points. Veronica Lake is great and the cast of memorable character actors is fun.
It rushes by so fast that it's hard to enjoy.
A classic in every sense of the word. It today's economic climate, this movie doesn't feel dated at all. It's funny, sweet and just an all around great movie.

"sullivan's travels" has more than a few laugh out loud bits, but the film is often too stupid instead of funny. especially toward the end, some bits really drag and i found my self glancing over at the time every now and again, wondering how much longer it would go on, which is pretty bad especially considering the movie's running time is merely an hour and a half.

This movie was probably a trend-setter at the time...and maybe all of the lazy jokes, over-used slapstick and stereotypical characters were breakthrough when first introduced, but man did this seem like a bad movie. How it rates #61 on the AFI chart is beyond me. On the plus, some interesting social commentary and a few themes that I've seen referenced in other shows/movies.
A movie director goes out into the real world to ivestigate the real world for his films, and ends up on a chain gang and presumably dead.
one of those perfect films and great introduction to veronica lake.
Sullivan's Travels is a comedic and at times surprisingly heartfelt tale of poverty and social justice.
Who could ever get too much Veronica Lake?
Flawed yet funny, Sullivan's Travels is a great movie, but it falls short of classic status.

An amazing film that highlights the importance of comedy as a genre. For all critics who inappropriately label comedies as unimportant and low rent this film acts as the perfect counterpoint. It shows how to some people a laugh is the only thing they have going for them.
Veronica Lake is adorable in this Social Satire/Comedy.  An interesting and enjoyable journey.  Recommended.

If you have ever seen the 1941 Preston Sturges classic, Sullivan's Travels, you know that there is a large paradoxical element in the film's overall narrative theme which states: It is enough to make a film which allows for an audiences simplistic enjoyment of the entertainment without any heavy-handed social message which often accompanies pictures which are deemed 'important' or concerning 'the human condition.' However, in making his picture, Sturges gives us both a wonderfully farcical comedy, a biting satire, and a socially conscious message film all in one. 

How than, would you say, does such a large order fill itself over the course of a 90 minute farce about a Hollywood director who wants to make a picture about suffering? Very well, in my humble opinion.
Really great comedy that has influenced many directors from Scorsese to the Coen Brothers.  I highly recommend checking this one out!

Starring Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake, with director Preston Sturges, Sullivan's Travels is about a highly successful film director (McCrea) who wants to make a movie about the common man and suffering. However, he usually writes comedies and so he decides to go on the road as a hobo to try and understand the lifestyle. During his adventures he meets a young failed actress (Lake) who is about to leave Hollywood. Wanting to help her, Sully tells the girl what he is doing and they go off together masquerading as tramps. After taking a short respite, he goes on the road again, this time alone. Through a series of events he finds himself in a chain gang while his friends assume he is dead. Eventually he is freed but not before learning a valuable lesson. If he wants to relate with the poor he should give them laughter instead of hardship. I found this movie to be an enjoyable  light comedy (even though I had never heard of it beforehand).
Veronica Lake's best, and one of Preston Sturges' standouts.

I wasn't blown away so much that I'm absolutely convinced of its essential addition to the AFI Top 100, but I was always engaged and never bored with the characters.  I can appreciate the satire, but films like this are difficult for someone of my generation to grasp entirely without the proper context.  I never felt emotionally invested and considering that "Citizen Kane" (which I loved) has topped the list twice, did we really need another entry on the list from 1941?

From writer-director Preston Sturges, Sullivan's Travels is the story of filmmaker John 'Sully' Sullivan disguising himself as a tramp in order to research his next picture. It's smart and funny in the way the best movies of the 1940s are, combining elements of slapstick physicality with wry witticisms and quick-fire quips. Similarly there is no dead weight being dragged along in the supporting cast, and Joel McCrea's excellent lead performance is only outshined by the radiance of a stunning Veronica Lake in her breakthrough role - even if she is more convincing dressed as a young boy than Ginger Rogers was as a young girl in The Major and the Minor. 

Sturges is probably best known for The Lady Eve, another brilliant comedy released the same year, but Sullivan's Travels may just surpass it in almost every way. The one thing that prevents the film from being perfect is the final act's dramatic turn, which isn't entirely successful. Taking itself more seriously and taking away the jokes and the girl, it risks losing those who were expecting both right to the end. Still, it's a great story, deftly told, never dull for a second, and it's up there with the best. A tribute to the importance of laughter that succeeds on every level.
so...........boring......... and the comedy is okay, but it's not very funny. The only thing that I find that makes this movie good/interesting: Veronica Lake.

499TH REVIEW: Preston Sturges' SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS [1941]

Sullivan: I want this picture to be a commentary on modern conditions, stark realism, the problems that confront the average man.

Lebrand: But with a little sex.

Sullivan: A little, but I don't want to stress it. I want this picture to be a document. I want to hold a mirror up to life. I want this to be a picture of dignity- a true canvas of the suffering of humanity.

Lebrand: But with a little sex.

Sullivan: (reluctantly).....But...... with a little sex in it.

Hadrian: How about a nice musical?

Sullivan: How can you talk about musicals at a time like this? With the world committing suicide, with corpses pilling up in the street, with grim death gargling at you from every corner, with people slaughtered like sheep!

Hadrian: Maybe they'd like to forget that.

Sullivan: Then why do they hold this one over for a fifth week over at the music hall? For the Ushers? 

Hadrian: It died in Pittsburgh.

Lebrand: Like a dog.

Sullivan: What do they know in Pittsburgh?

Lebrand: They know what they like. 

Sullivan: If they knew what they like they wouldn't live in Pittsburgh. That's no argument.

Seventy Years Ago in the year 1941 the world was going through utter hell. The Second World War by now had consumed most of Europe, Russia, Africa,  Asia  & The Pacific and was in its full second year of running while in the largely unaffected U.S.A had just gotten over the Great Depression. The U.S.A was yet to suffer firsthand the horrors of the last global conflict which would come towards the end of 1941 on that fateful day in Hawaii on December 7th 1941. Until then the U.S was still in peacetime when Hollywood produced three of the finest movies of all time. These were of course were Orson Welles' CITIZEN KANE, John Huston's THE MALTESE FALCON & Preston Sturges' SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS.
 
REVIEW # 499: SULLIVAN'S ODYSSEY, A LOOK AT A GREAT HOLLYWOOD FILM.

Much like Charlie Chaplin's iconic Tramp and his many comical Odysseys, SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS sees an important Hollywood director of dumb Hollywood comedies called John. L. Sullivan played by Joel McCrea (RIDE IN THE HIGH COUNTRY) who wants to adapt the Novel "O Brother Were Art Thou?" a story about poverty and Human suffering to the big screen. After learning from his studio bosses that he knows nothing about trouble, poverty and Human suffering Sullivan hits the road disguised as a Tramp. Sullivan learns an important message about not human suffering but the value of humour, comedy, escapism, and above all the value of laughter. Something that today and over 70 years ago was ever so important in a time of hardship. 

 SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS for a comedy from comedic legend Preston Sturges wrote & directed exactly 70 years ago in such a turbulent time is a film of two half's as most people have written about the film. The first half of the film is a light hearted slapstick swipe at the Hollywood system and the second half is a stirring melodrama about poverty, the class divided and something not seen in a Hollywood film of its time depicted African-Americans in a positive light. After seeing this film and reaching the milestones of my 499th, 500th & 501st reviews on this site, I decided it was important to me that one these three reviews would be about a film that had long fascinated me after learning about this 1941 masterpiece. In this special feature length essay-review I'm going to review and explain why SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS is a true masterpiece of comedy.


THE PLOTLINE

After failing to impress studio Bosses Hadrian & Lebrand with his new movie, director John Sullivan has his heart set on making a film about suffering called 'O BROTHER WERE ART THOU?". However the studio bosses are reluctant to back the idea, and remind Sullivan how he has never known about suffering over his safe upbringing and cushy life style complete with a wife who serves no better purpose than for a tax break. Sullivan determined to understand what it means to be without name and without a check book decides to dress up like a tramp with no more than 10c in his pocket and hit the road. However everyone including Sullivan's Butlers & the studio are not impressed by the idea. The studio has Sullivan watched by a Caravan filled with doctors, reporters, studio personal and even a cook to make sure no real harm falls upon him. After trying desperately to ditch the caravan Sullivan soon comes to the agreement with the crew that if they let him experience trouble first hand by himself then he will meet back up with them in Las Vegas in a few weeks time. In the meantime Sullivan begins an odyssey, which goes wrong after falling into the clutches of a needy widow and her friend. Sullivan quickly escapes from the Widow's farm and hitches a ride on the back of a truck. Upon the truck stopping in downtown L.A, Sullivan is disheartened that he has ended back in Hollywood.


After getting some breakfast in a rundown diner Sullivan comes across a failed young actress (played brilliantly by Veronica Lake) who complains to Sullivan about how hard it is to make a break in the movie industry. Sullivan becomes friendly with the girl and decides to borrow his own car and drive her home, however the pair end up in jail when Sullivan's butlers realises who the tramp is. The Actress is less than impress that Sullivan isn't the failed filmmaker and tramp he proclaimed to be, but after he explains why he was dress as a tramp the young actress wants to join him on his journey. Despite his reluctant attitude, Sullivan and the girl soon hit the road together and together Sullivan and the girl learn what it is like to be in poverty. In a silent montage Sullivan & The Girl grow closer while travelling across The U.S.A amongst the poor and hungry, upon nearly eating out of the trash Sullivan and The Girl return to the studio crew and a well off lifestyle.
 
But not before Sullivan decides to hand out a pile of cash in disguises as the tramp for one last time to the tramps for what they had shown him. One greedy Tramp assaults Sullivan steals his money, shoes with his I.D cards in the soles and leaves him for dead on a train. The Greedy tramp is soon killed on the rail tracks with the I.D card shoes. After not coming back to the Girl and the studio crew, a search begins for Sullivan which ends up with the wrong conclusion in the city morgue with the dead bum. Sullivan arrives on the train in  a rail-yard somewhere in the deep South of the country were disoriented Sullivan hits a railway yard worker which sees Sullivan being imprisoned for six years on a Southern Chain-Gang.  Sullivan desperately wants to get back to L.A and tries anything to get out of the gang especially after in a Gospel Church amidst a crowd of laughing people, Sullivan learns the value of comedy.  Sullivan decides to claim that he was the killer of the dead Hollywood director John Sullivan in the hope he would get media attention and be freed from the Chain gang.


THE ACTING, SCRIPTING AND DIRECTION.

This film has many great performances in this film, from what I have found out about writer-director Preston Sturges is that he is considered the father of screwball comedy. One aspect of Sturges auteur style was that he would give the punch-lines to not always the main characters but rather to the secondary characters. The dialogue such as the excerpt at the start of the review is just amazing and how it's delivered to start with such speed it comes so quick and fast is also amazing. Later in the film Sturges comedic style fades away for a grim social melodrama like the scenes of Sullivan & the girl experiencing the hardships of life on the road, The chain gang sequence and of course the moving church sequence which are all done in a masterful way. 
  
The two performances that I will talk about are of course Joel McCrea & Veronica Lake. McCrea I have seen in another great film and poetic by Sam Peckinpah called RIDE IN THE COUNTRY made in 1962, were McCrea plays an ill fated aging lawman who longs to enter his house justified. McCrea much like in that film is brilliant in this film as John Sullivan. Alongside Veronica Lake who also is just brilliant as 'The Girl" (because no name is given for her character), both McCrea & Lake are great together.


THE CHURCH SEQUENCE AND ITS HISTORICAL IMPORTANCE 
 
 One of the most celebrated moments in this film occurs deep within the film when the chain gang and Sullivan are escorted into a Black Church to see a movie. After seeing the Minister ask his parishioners that they are going to have a bit of entertainment with people less fortunate than themselves and asking them not to judge them because they are all equal in the eyes of God. The doors open to the chain gang while they shuffle in the parishioners sing GO DOWN MOSES   to them. When the projector starts to screen a Pluto cartoon, everyone in the church is seen laughing together. 70 years after this film was made a scene like this is viewed as a normal thing, however in 1941 for African-Americans to be shown in a respectful light in a Hollywood film was almost alien. For a black people to be shown than anything other than inferiors was common place in most Hollywood films of the time.

 The church sequence in SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS attracted positive feedback from most liberal whites and African- American's.  Preston Sturges received a letter from NAACP secretary Walter White congratulating him for the scene, "I want to congratulate and thank you for the church sequence in Sullivan's Travels. This is one of the most moving scenes I have seen in a moving picture for a long time. But I am particularly grateful to you, as are a number of my friends, both white and colored, for the dignified and decent treatment of Negroes in this scene. I was in Hollywood recently and am to return there soon for conferences with production heads, writers, directors, and actors and actresses in an effort to induce broader and more decent picturization of the Negro instead of limiting him to menial or comic roles. The sequence in Sullivan's Travels is a step in that direction and I want you to know how grateful we are".  In a way SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS was one of the first Hollywood films to portray African-Americans in an equal and dignified light, sadly it would take another 15 to 25 years before Hollywood changed for the better. 

OVERALL THOUGHTS  

SULLIVAN'S TRAVELS as I have mention is one truly great film; in fact its ground breaking portrayal of African Americans, satire of the Hollywood system, and a stirring reminder of the value of laughter makes this film a truly great movie. The only thing this film has denied is a wider audience, which is what it really needs. Personally along with a few other classic films from the 1940's, this film is without a doubt one of my all time favourite movies. My rating is a solid 100% for this great movie.
I think the film Sullivan should've made after the end is the Coen Brothers version of O Brother, Where Art Thou?

This is an absolutely brilliant film that has a lot more messages than meets the eye. I was more so expecting this to be a straight screwball comedy, but it had much more under the surface and more tragic and thought provoking sequences.  The characters, cast, and especially the writing are all perfection. Even the slightest minor characters have deep thoughts and striking personalities. I'm still honestly not getting the completely random hanging legs at around the 55 minute mark when McCrea and Lake are walking near the water.

Beyond meta-film and beyond screwball comedy, Sullivan's Travels is a breathtaking adventure ahead of its time. The process of filmmaking inspiration had never met such an unusual turn, but Sturges was the man for the job. This may be the first masterpiece to celebrate the movie industry with predominant passion (and some inside spoofs and jokes). Veronica Lake is a stunning fox in here!

99/100

Perhaps the most iconic role of chic blonde bombshell Veronica Lake ever had, "Sullivan's Travels" is yet another excellent Preston Sturges comedy that stings more than it makes you laugh, which isn't necessarily a bad thing when it comes to a satirical piece like this one.  It may not be as hilarious as Sturges' "other" 1941 film, "The Lady Eve," but "Sullivan's Travels" is a bit more thoughtful, and by the time everything's wrapped up, it raises lots of questions that one wouldn't ordinarily think of.
	Joel McCrea, a Sturges favorite, portrays John L. Sullivan, a somewhat successful director that has made a profitable career out of making frothy comedies.  But after a screening of his upcoming film, Sullivan decides to put his career on halt and discover the true nature of human tragedy by living it himself.  After all, the next film he's planning to direct is "O Brother, Where Art Thou?"
	So he picks up some roughed-up clothes, dirties himself, and hits the road, with his staff tailing him in a luxurious van (much to his dislike).  He picks up a bitter actress (Lake) who's fed up with the phoniness of the movie industrey, and the attractive twosome go on a penniless journey together; they quickly lean that the "tramp" lifestyle isn't so bad, as long as you're able to get by.  
	McCrea and Lake are such a smart couple on the screen that it's surprising that behind the screen they loathed each other greatly.
	A slinky combination of dry comedy and depression era-esque drama, "Sullivan's Travels" keeps the basic Hollywood formula of "comedy" in mind and, instead of putting up the good-old usual, it almost examines it.  And it isn't at all subtle, considering the main character of the film is sick of comedies, and wants to see what the darker sides of life can offer.
	"Sullivan's Travels" instantly makes you think of the majority of films during wartime, most of them being cute, escapist comedies or Technicolor-laden musical spectacles, with just a few that come to mind about real human tragedy.  But at a time where the nation as a whole NEEDED to escape from all of the hardships of real life, it isn't at all a surprise.  Who would want to see a sad melodrama during a difficult time? In the end, "Sullivan's Travels" is almost a journey discovering why a simple, fluffy laugh is much more enticing than a tear-jerker.
	This is discovered later in the film, when Sullivan is sent to a labor camp.  The work is largely difficult: the "employees" have to work in the hot sun all-day, hardly with any breaks.  Everyone there is miserable, put frankly.  There's a scene, set around this labor camp, in a church, where all of the workers get the chance to go to "the picture show," as one character puts it.  Along with the churchgoers, the workers get to see a Mickey Mouse cartoon.  The cartoon takes them away from their hellish life, gives them a good time, and a warm dose of happiness.
	It is such a beautiful scene-- Sturges brilliantly focuses the camera on individual workers' expressions.  Many of their faces are covered in mud and sweat, but their smiles are huge, and their laughs hide their misery.  In that moment, Sullivan discovers why tragedy films aren't attractive to anyone, and just a few minutes, the film ends.  And it couldn't be better.
	Sturges' writing and directing is 100% perfect.  This film is so fresh, funny, lovely, touching, and biting that it almost seems surprising that something so feel-good can also be razor sharp.  "Sullivan's Travels" is brilliant.
Great screwball comedy and social commentary from Sturgis

#61 on AFI's Top 100 Movie's List.  Better than expected (good twist ending that gets the message that making people laugh is more important than portraying serious messages in movies), but not really sure why it is considered a top movie of all time.

Pretty awesome movie about the power of laughter during the rough parts of life. The first scene between Veronica Lake and Joel McCrea is absolute perfect screenwriting. Not a dull moment in the whole moment.

A much beloved movie about a movie movie that's at times pretty wonky and silly and at others actually quite dark and serious, while striking a pretty good balance between both. The big draw of this movie is obviously the often worshiped Veronica Lake, but frequent Struges collaborator Joel McCrea is great too. I definitely liked the last half better than the first, but this is an entertaining, fun little romp overall.
The slapstick comedy bits fall flat at times and there are a few questionable plot conveniences, but for the most part it's pretty funny and intelligent, and the concept is great.
I am a fan of Veronica Lake, and this movie is gorgeous... beautiful cinematography for the time.

The films approach feels terribly sophisticated considering when it was made, with some elements even coming across as post-modern. It is also incredibly good natured, in a manner that isn't patronising. 

If I'm being honest, I wonder if it was made today would I have such a high opinion of it. But at the same time, if it hadn't been made who knows what wartime shite might have taken its place as the yardstick for clever comedy. 

If the vision of today's standard comedy fare is just as erudite and sharp, its only because they are standing on the shoulders of the gently satirical giants that paved the way. This film is one of those giants.

oh, and Veronica Lake is a stone cold fox.

This film has it all, slapstick comedy, wisecracking one liners, attempted murder, Veronica Lake dressing up as a very convincing boy....everything.

Preston Sturges seems to have a lot of fun getting his Depression-era message across and even manages to perfectly validate the films attempt to franticly (and jokily) cover all bases to cater to the widest audience. Clever bloke.

The writing is bang on and direction is playful. The church scene is a real golden moment in a film full of wonderful moments.

A well-done comedy, that takes a dark turn late in the film, but ends with Sullivan recognizing that his journey to understand the tramps of the world has led him to realize that, for some, comedy is all they have to make the day go down easy. The first half of the film I found particularly hilarious, especially the bus-chasing scene which had me in stitches. McCrea and Lake were a fine pairing, and I enjoyed watching them learn more about living town-to-town. The film does feel a bit long, particularly after Sullivan was "killed" (excepting for the picture show scene). Regardless, a very good film about a man's journey to learn about another part of society.
Seriously silly Sturges.
Brilliant, witty screenplay and a story that takes a thoughtful look at the impact of the Great Depression on the common man and woman.

One of only 13 films written & directed by Preston Sturges, and one of his few failures at the time. Critically panned and not a big commercial success either, it eventually came to be seen as his most accomplished work by future cinemaniacs. 

I understand contemporary reviewers' opinion that Sturges doesn't follow his own message: films should be funny, not drown in messages that most people don't understand or care about. The conundrum of course is that making a film with that specific message becomes automatically self-defeating. I admit freely to having had a lot more fun watching that other Sturges film "The Lady Eve". But if you don't get hung up in the 'message controversy'", Sullivan offers a couple of good laughs, a lot of (very fake, as it turned out) chemistry between McCrea & Lake, and some cinematic grand-standing in long sweeping camera shots. 

Made in Veronica Lake's heyday, just before she began succumbing to mental illness that saw her become one of Hollywood's more tragic stories, and worthy of a film in its own right (I would actually really like to see that film, provided it's well done and they get a good actress, like Amy Addams perhaps). Lake was 6 to 8 months pregnant over the course of filming, a fact she had not advised Sturges about until her contract was signed, which caused him to nearly assault her. Costume designers did a remarkable job hiding it, since nowhere does she look preggers. When aware of the fact, there's a couple of scenes towards the end of the film, when her characters runs (and falls, not scripted, hearts must have stopped when that happened), in which you can see HOW they hid her belly, but if you wouldn't know that, you'd barely notice. 

Other than  her advanced state, McCrea loathed Lake so violently that he refused to star in "I married a witch", stating that life is too short to make two films with Veronica. Eventual co-star in "I married a witch" apparently agreed, though he found one film too much in hindsight. Lake's talent is often derided, but here I found her compelling, convincing & charming, and since the mutual loathing between the stars, she sure acts her infatuation very well.
#61 - AFI top 100 Movies, 2007 ed.

Very clever.  Very funny.

Veronica Lake is absolutely gorgeous.
Sturges' masterpiece, "Sullivan's Travels" boasts a pitch-perfect balance of humor and heart.
a brilliant comedy about the importance of brilliant comedies

A very gentle social commentary film that is very enjoyable. It's got a easy light sense of humour and while none of its observations on the world and class are earth shattering, they are none the less relevant. The overall tone of the film is a tad naive and it's quite glossy, even when depicting the homeless. The ending is a bit ridiculous, but so is the overall plot of the film. It walks that line very well, never crossing it into absurdity.

It may not be as good as Sturges' "The Lady Eve," but "Sullivan's Travels" is an absolutely lovely, very likable film from the early 1940's. The film follows the life of director, played Joel McCrea, who wants to make a movie on tramps (today it would translated as bums or hobos). The way he does this is lives like a bum and along the way (in Hollywood of all places) he finds Veronica Lake ("The Girl" as she is credited) and its history from there. The film has some fine lines ("You don't know anything about anything") and sharp comedy, as well as some beautiful tenderness, exposing the love between McCrea and Lakes' characters plus the emphasis of the hobos' lifestyle. The only critiscm I have towards this film is the first ten minutes, which seem a bit slow and bereaved of laughs, that's all. It is a lovely film to watch and a good comedy from the 1940's.

So letâ(TM)s pretend for a second that youâ(TM)re going to set out to make a movie about the ravaged economy and what it is like to be a hobo, riding the rails and stealing shoes in the night for your own feet.  You might think you need a better idea to base your movie on and you might be right but for the Sullivan of our film here, he decides research is not enough to get to the heart of this matter.  He opts to travel the country as a bum, along with the first-class bum entourage sweeping the nation (actually, he insists his Hollywood staff remain behind but they insist on tagging along and itâ(TM)s a good thing, too â" they actually make for some of the most bluntly honest stuff Sturges ever wrote).  Shortly into the trip, he falls in love with a down-on-her-luck gal hoping to hit it big and before you can say âGee, I wonder how this is going to end up,â sheâ(TM)s hopping trains, sleeping on streets and learning the ways of the bum, albeit it in disguise (I guess there is no such thing as female bums in this universe?).  Everyone learns a valuable lesson but then it dawns on your that thereâ(TM)s still another 20 minutes to play out and you wonder where this can possibly go.  Turns out thereâ(TM)s another lesson or seven to learn, from Disneyâ(TM)s Pluto of all things, and this is where the film stumbles a bit.  Look, Sturges knows what he is doing and his writing elevates already solid performances from everyone in this (youâ(TM)d be hard pressed to find someone not holding up their end of the acting agreement) but for whatever reason, the final few scenes left a horrid taste in my mouth.  And yeah, thatâ(TM)s probably a cheap reason to dock a movie in its score but really now: you watch the end of this and tell me if it had the intended effect on youâ¦ and if it did, well, then clearly you and I havenâ(TM)t hung out enough.

Very good. Not anywhere near as nasty as most Hollywood satires, but then it doesn't wholly fit into that subgenre. Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake aren't the greatest performers around, but I like them just fine, and they've got the appropriate chemistry. I disliked the third-act device of amnesia, and the rather forced and obvious ending, but no matter. An entertaining piece of work all the same.
An original picture of it's time, at the it's borrow from the silence slapstick era. It's funny, it's a movie for all time, for all. So just relacs and enjoy.

This movie is hilarious! There's so many one-liners. The third act takes a bizarre tone-shift, but the film remains interesting. I just wish they'd have kept it going a-laugh-a-minute like the first part of the film. It kind of echoed (or, rather, served as a precursor to) "Adaptation", in that sense.
A movie all movie lovers should see.
Good comedy, with some little flaws in the plot, but the rest is excellent. Great ending.
Why we love the movies.

Cushy Hollywood director John L. Sullivan wants to direct a tragedy, but his producers point out that he has never really undergone hardship. He sets out with a raggedy suit of clothes and 10 cents in order to be a tramp, and along the way he meets a bunch of people and gets in a lot of trouble.

At a short 90 minutes, it still manages to convey a good story. A rich director with no knowledge of the Depression simply plays the tramp for most of the film until the half way point where he really does become a tramp. Sullivan discovers that people with nothing still want entertainment, which leads him to complete a small but satisfying character arc.

Veronica Lake is also very impressive as The Girl. An attractive buy sassy young woman who buys John breakfast becomes his sidekick and love interest which also adds another dimension the script.

Its truly the moments without dialogue that have some of the most emphasis. There are multiple montage scenes all around which convey what needs to be done, without the amount of cliche scenes that would normally entail.

All together a well plotted and well scripted little comedy. The chemistry between Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake is genuine, and it ends up being one of the best movies about movies ever made.
Oh, this movie was hilarious!  Some scenes may get a little too silly, but overall it works.  I highly recommend this great screwball comedy.
mr. Sturges was very intelligen fella...and brave - for the 40's. great.
Some great, witty, quick dialogue scenes, and the montage scenes are quite good.
And now I finally understand where "O, Brother Where Art Thou?" comes from. Nice. Oh... and I never realized how absolutely lovely Veronica Lake was. Wow!!

One of the best scripts that ever came out of Hollywood, Sullivan's Travels proves Preston Sturges was one of a kind.A perfect mix of comedy, drama and social commentary, this film is a must-see for anyone who really loves movies!

Burrows: You see, sir, rich people and theorists - who are usually rich people - think of poverty in the negative, as the lack of riches - as disease might be called the lack of health. But it isn't, sir. Poverty is not the lack of anything, but a positive plague, virulent in itself, contagious as cholera, with filth, criminality, vice and despair as only a few of its symptoms. It is to be stayed away from, even for purposes of study. It is to be shunned.

Great film!  This movie had really good shots that conveyed good acting, although over the top with dry wit and humor. Timeless satire on the importance of comedies in film. Veronica Lake is too sweet & unforgettably charming  as "The Girl," & Joel McCrea is great as the popular, young, successful Hollywood director, in search of making a more meaningful film.

The brief clip at the beginning from "O Brother, Where Art Thou?", the film within the film, is so stirring that one wonders what would have happened had Sturges directed a similar bleak project. "Sullivan's Travels" is a skillful tightrope walk over real human suffering, with one misstep threatening to send the whole thing crashing down into the realms of bad taste. World War II broke out shortly before this movie was released and there were suddenly much bigger problems to deal with, much more dire concerns on the public's mind.  

Unfortunate, since this film should have been a huge hit. "Sullivan's Travels" became a reflection of a naive pre-war mindset, and its honest attempts to deal with social reform fell on blind eyes. It's a very tight, very funny film with a perfect mix of slapstick and wit.
Wonderful screenplay, I really like the way the film is cynical with itself and the industry, one of the best inside industry movies. Joel MacCrea and Veronica Lake are great.-
Still pertinent (sometimes drawn-out) Hollywood satire, filled with brilliant dialogue. First & final thirds are great. Seems more relevant than ever to today's Australian film industry.

This is about the best Black & White Movie I have seen in sometime. Veronica Lake was nothing short of great and beautiful, her acting couldn't be touched by any other actress in this film. She was a beautiful lady.  This movie starts out and one wonders if they are in for a slow boring film, but within 15 minutes it picks up and what we have is a wonderful story for the 1941 time frame. Joel McCrea plays a big time movie producer who is going to put out a movie about hard times, but what does he know about hard times, so he goes on the road as a hobo, meets Veronica Lake and she joins him on his quest. All in all it makes for a pretty good movie, worth the rental, if your a Pre 1960 film collector this one needs to be in it, no big name stars but an excellent movie overall. 4 Stars

I'll admit it--I'd be a sucker for Veronica Lake.  She could wrap me around her finger with no effort.  This is my favorite of her films, and of Joel McCrea's films, and of brilliant director Preston Sturges.  Way ahead of its time, "Sullivan's Travels" starts out as a slapstick comedy in the unreal world of Hollywood.  But as McCrea and Lake head out into the real world, the laughs get more and more reality-based and then drama takes over as the truth of life in Depression-era America falls on our hapless hero like a ton of bricks.  Alternating laughs with keen social comedy, Sturges gives us a film that reminds us to accept ourselves and our place in the world.
Great movie. Rarely seen on TV. Sums up my outlook on life. Be thankful for what you have because there are others who wish they had what you have. Life sucks without laughter.

A film director wants to make a movie called 'O Brother Where Art Thou' and decides the best way to do research on this serious picture about the poor is to dress up like a hobo and try to live off the ten cents in his pocket.
Lots of great bits of banter and while I wasn't fussy for the main character, everybody who surrounds him is a joy.  The scene where Veronica Lake buys him the ham and eggs is the best scene in the movie and she's a pleasure to watch in this one.
Sullivan's Travels is a very important, life changing film. And you won't know it till the last scene.

I have two goals for this project this weekend. One is to get my total of AFI movies watched to at least ten. The second is to have enough cash left over in this pay period to place a half.com order for a few of the ones that are expensive at Best Buy and not available to rent on Amazon. Here's hoping.

The order Im picking to watch movies is pretty random. Since I've seen about 1/4 of them before, Im trying to keep those repeats spread out to every 4th movie. Also trying to balance the online vs offline movies. Right now the strategy for picking online movies is to first go for the ones that would be most expensive to otherwise get at Best Buy. Sullivan's Travels would have actually been the most expensive purchase, according to bestbuy.com So its priority was upped and I watched it just now. Wow that paragraph was boring. Sorry, peeps.

Mixed feelings about this one. There were points when I thought it was one of the greatest comedies Ive ever seen, and points when I found it kinda dull. Mostly the good outweighs the bad. The dialogue (which you'll learn is prolly the most important thing in a movie for me) was smart and snappy, especially in some of the opening scenes, which I absolutely loved. But the slapstick that was sprinkled into that was a bit too much for my taste. I think thats because I tend to find visual humor very predictable, whereas quick dialogue is more likely to surprise me. That's also why I like offensive humor, but thats not applicable to this film.

My big complaint, however, is that while watching the film, it felt kinda disjointed. The main plot line wrapped up earlier than I expected, and then the story took a weird twist kinda late on. By then I was kinda ready to file this movie away, not start on some new train of thought. It all got wrapped up very nicely, but it wasnt until those final moments that it all made sense. Until then that last half hour was just awkward.

Another thing Im on the fence about is that there were a lot of sequences without any dialogue. Some of them were beautiful, others boring. Ultimately, I do think it was a nice touch, I guess I just didnt have the attention span.

What I am completely sold on in this movie, was Veronica Lake's performance. I just loved her. She has that 1940's glam but she was also one tough cookie. This may actually be the first time that I see a character from such a far back time period who I wish I was. Sadly a quick IMDB check shows that I wont be encountering Ms Lake in any other AFI films, but she did make a zombie movie in the 70's. May hafta scope that one out later.

Im just not enough in the writing flow right now to come up with any more comments on this one. I very much enjoyed the first hour, but the rest of the 90 minutes just lost me.

From director Preston Sturges, a former Broadway writer who had gone to Hollywood and made moderately successful films like The Great McGinty and The Lady Eve, comes this off-the-wall comedy with a down to earth quality. Although not a big success upon it's original release, it's now considered to be one of the best films ever made, like Citizen Kane really, but this has stood the test of time. It has John L. Sullivan (Joel McCrea), a young director working in Hollywood who has hit it big, although the films he makes are successful, he's unsatisfied with them, and he wants to make a film about the plight of the less fortunate, to be titled O Brother, Where Art Thou? He decides to try and live his life as a hobo, but the studio head Mr. Lebrand (Robert Warwick) is keeping tabs on him by following him around, Sullivan gets help from a down-on-her-luck aspiring actress known as The Girl (Veronica Lake), but his plans go slightly awry. It is a genuinely funny film with some brilliant dialogue within. It comes from the golden ages of the screwball comedies that came out of Hollywood at that time. McCrea was a brilliant leading man back then, and he sparks wonderfully of everyone he comes into contact with. Sturges' dialogue is brilliant, and has influenced many. The Coen's were heavily inspired by this for one of their films, can you guess which one??
They don't make them like this anymore! Well, some of them do, I suppose. But not Preston Sturges, because he's dead.
The best movie about movies in my opinion, next to Sunset Blvd. You can't really go wrong with this one. Good story, good message, good acting, good direction. Oh, and Veronica Lake.

One of the great American comedies. A solid classic and close to flawless from beginning to end, super-intelligent and very funny, it's easy to see why the Coens dig it so much. Nicely satirizes its target (self-important Hollywood types who are on a mission to save the world) in a way that is never mean-spirited. The careful balance between comedy and drama is so skillfully handled you never find yourself thinking "Is this a comedy, or a drama?"  And the concluding "moral" of the story might seem like a bathetic one, but it is meaningful and true...maybe comedies can't save the world but they can make it laugh. And that's not such a bad thing, if that happens to be your job

It is with a sharp satirical edge and self-referential humour that writer/director Preston Sturges charts the misadventures of a film director who takes a penniless expedition in search for inspiration. With just the right doses of slapstick comedy, crackerjack dialogue, and pointed one-liners ("If people in Pittsburgh knew what they liked they wouldn't live in Pittsburgh"), "Sullivanâs Travels" is a movie about human suffering made fun. Joel McCrea is great as the titular director, and Veronica Lake's flirty acting style fits the material nicely. The plot takes an interesting turn about halfway through which makes things quite a bit less funny, but makes the transformation of McCrea's character more complete, and ties together the point of the story: "There's something to be said for making people laugh. It's all some people have. It's not much, but it counts for something in this cockeyed caravan."

It's a classic and one I recommend to all my young trainhopping friends. Interesting trivia: Preston Sturges' mother was one of Aleister Crowley's lovers, and for a few years, he was raised by the two of them. Doesn't surprise me that both had terrible things to say about each other!

Sullivan's Travels is a little dated in terms of its humor, but for the most part, it's still a wonderful satire on Hollywood, comedies in general, and the relationship between the rich and poor. Joel McCrea plays John Sullivan, a famous Hollywood director notorious for making throwaway comedies. When he decides to make a serious and meaningful drama about the poor, titled "O Brother Where Art Thou?" the studio heads accuse Sullivan of knowing nothing about the poor, and they think that no audience member would want to see a movie so serious. So Sullivan makes a plan to live as a hobo until he is able to feel the poor man's plight. His life as a hobo is quite funny because every time he runs into a tough situation, he returns to his normal life full of wealth and power to fix it. Along the way, he meets an aspiring actress played beautifully by Veronica Lake. They quickly hit it off and slowly start to fall in love. Oh, but Sullivan is already married to another woman. He married her because it would save him tens of thousands of dollars on his taxes. What's a guy to do? The whole storyline of this is played to great comedic effect. Lake and McCrea sizzle on-screen together, and Sullivan's butlers provide a lot of comedic relief. It kind of reminded me of a French farce where the butlers know all! It was also cool to see that the Coen Brothers referenced this movie in their films. There's a scene where a picture of the "man of the house" keeps changing expressions, similar to the Coens' "The Ladykillers" and the title of "O Brother Where Art Thou?" is used in their 2000 film starring George Clooney. The movie also changes tone to great effect towards the end where Sullivan is actually forced to work as a poor man. We definitely see his change in attitude when he no longer has his "rich man safety net". It's a great contrast to the rest of the film, and definitely helps hit the satirical elements home.

While this movie plays up its cheesiness a bit in a satirical way, there are some instances where I felt it was just cheesy 40s comedy without the satirical overtones. There's an instance where all of the characters in the scene throw each other into the pool (its a little much), and some of Sullivan's lines just come across as pure cheese. It's kind of a forgivable flaw considering this was made 68 years ago, back when comedy was a lot different, but it was just kind of a shame to see that not all of the scenes aged as well as others.

Other than that, this is a wonderful satire that you should definitely check out. I haven't seen Veronica Lake in any other movie so far, but this is supposed to be one of her best roles, and she is just so sexy in this film. Her line delivery is full of sarcasm, and it's just a fun character for her to play. See this film!
Very enjoyable light hearted movie. With a quality message about the power of laughter. The last 30 minutes seemed quite rushed though and took something away from the movie as a whole.

Sullivan's Travels is a remarkable film that completely opened my eyes to 'older' movies. Prior to seeing Sullivan's Travels, I hesitated to see most movies made prior to the mid 60's as I feel the acting in many of them to be wooden and the characters hard to relate to. Sullivan's Travels (and the films of Preston Sturges in general) have changed this for me (and Sullivan's Travels is my favorite Sturges film I've seen so far). This is an all out hilarious, touching and even stylish film that's all the better with the criterion supplements that point out all the subtle ways in which Sturges was pushing the envelope that one might not notice if they weren't alive in the 1940's. This is a truly superb film that excels on every level. But you could also just see it for Veronica Lake.

As one of American cinema's earliest auteurs and cutting a distinctly modern figure (his mother's best friend was Isadora Duncan; he spent his youth criss-crossing the Atlantic; a "kiss-proof" lipstick and ticker-tape machine were among his patented inventions), Preston Sturges was responsible for an explosion of now-classic films in the 1940's. These films are known for their sophisticated verbal wit, uproarious physical comedy, and their affectionate portrayal of eccentric, scene-stealing supporting characters. But Sturges's work is also consistent in its exploration of the possibilities and prospects of upward - and occasionally downward - mobility. In what may be his finest, most complex film, Sullivan's Travels(1942), Sturges brilliantly mixes broad humor with sharp-edged cultural commentary, once again - as in The Great McGinty(1940), Christmas in July(1940), and The Lady Eve(1941) - revealing social identity to be a highly unstable proposition, capable of hyperbolic transformation through such prosaic means as disguise, confusion, and self-deception.
John L. Sullivan (Joel McCrea) is a can't-miss Hollywood director who specializes in lightweight entertainment, exemplified by broad comedies such as the 1939 film Ants in Your Pants. Naive and sheltered by a solicitous staff who have no interest in seeing their meal ticket change genres or become overly ambitious in his cinematic pursuits, Sully nonetheless sets his sights on directing an epic social commentary picture about tough times in depression-era America, to be entitled O Brother, Where Art Thou? (a fictional title eventually used by the Coen Brothers for their own 2000 film, in a clever tribute to Sturges). To research his topic, which involves such unpleasantries as suffering, deprivation, and racial inequality Sully insists on disguising himself as a hobo and making his way across the country to experience "real life" firsthand.
Once on the road, assorted adventures, meetings (notably with Veronica Lake's down-on-her-luck ingenue), and mishaps - some hilarious, others surprisingly poignant - transpire before Sully eventually comes to terms with his true calling as a lowbrow moviemaker with a gift for making people laugh. The lesson here is that strained seriousness and forced profundity have far less benefit for the masses than good old-fashioned humor, with its power to help people forget their troubles, if only for a while.
That Sullivan's Travels possesses an autobiographical dimension is impossible to deny, with Sturges affirming the value of what he himself did best - making smart comedies with the power to lift viewers' spirits - while ripping the pretentiousness of Hollywood's more sober and "socially committed" filmmakers. Personal statements aside, however, the tour de force script brings together a remarkable range of genres, including slapstick, action, melodrama, social documentary, romance, musical, and prison movie. Though it failed to garner a single Oscar nomination, Sullivan's Travels is the most remarkable film in the career of one America's greatest filmmakers.

An interesting concoction, the film begins as a witty satire on the questionable authenticity of Hollywood productions with rapid-fire wordplay and colourful supporting characters. But in its second act, abruptly changes pace, becoming more of a wrenching drama as the protagonist is submitted to misfortune after misfortune, which, giving his earlier self-righteous quest to "find real trouble", feel strangely fitting though hard to watch. Finally, the film's ending abruptly flips to an ending celebrating the importance of film comedy, which feels simultaneously heartwarming and a smarmy joke at once. It is difficult for the most part to decipher exactly what Sturges' motivation for approaching his subject matter from such unconventional angles is, but the power of his work cannot be argued, and the flipping from comedy to drama feels far more functional than imbalanced, strangely enough. An oddity worth seeing, but better to approach not expecting it to be a comedy.
The humor, plot twists, and message still hold up. Great film.

I didn't really like the way the plot unfolded in the third act, but the rest of the movie is very good. I really wanted to like this movie.  But unfortunately its just not funny.  All of the comedy in the first half of the film are rehashes of Charlie Chaplin bits, which just made me wish I was watching a CC movie. 

The second half almost redeems the disappointing first half, but not because it becomes funny. Ironically enough, the plot narrative that leads to the endorsement of comedies is the only part of the film that works. 

So when Sullivan's Travels tries to be a comedy, it fails; but when it tries to be a drama that honors comedies, it succeeds.

One more item: Veronica Lake is wonderful here. She deserves special mention for helping me endure to the second half when the film finally finds its legs.

Preston Sturges is an unsung comedy king, and this is his greatest, about a famous director of comedies aching to make a legit drama, from a director of comedies who was aching to make a drama. Get it? No matter, it's a damn good time.

Another one of those great films about the making of films. It is aware of itself but not too much, just enough to make its point: Films can be made to talk about social issues, but a lot of times it just needs to make people laugh. I loved it as soon as the dialogue started and even more so when the great Veronica Lake appeared onscreen. Watch and enjoy this gem of a film.

Finally got around to seeing this one. Definitely one of the best of the era - so cynical and frank in its messages, very much in the same vein as Sunset Boulevard/Singin' in the Rain/Ace in the Hole (I guess one should say the latter are much in the same vein as this because of that horrible thing called chronology...but whatever). Regardless, great film that blends comedy with social commentary... dey don't make 'em like dey useta, dey shore don'....
I finally understand the title for the Coen brothers' movie "O' Brother Where Art Thou?".

Enjoyable and touching. On the fringe of must-see. This movie isn't very complicated, but in such utterly compelling fashion evaluates the role of cinema in society. (But don't worry, its very artfully worked into the story). Sometimes simple is better.
A great film about making a film is first class entertainment.

This movie is rated high in the AFA's greatest films of all time and I now know why. It explored one of the biggest social issues of its day with both depth and comedy, all without making light of it. I loved it and would recommend it to anyone!
One of the best American films of the 40's, Preston Sturges masterpiece imo.
yikes, this movie was good, i sort of knew it would be considering that criterion had released a version of it, but still, it was pretty good.

Decent enough, but a little overrated as far as the script goes. Veronica Lake is quite nice to watch...it's a shame she so ofen was jipped on good sreenplays, resulting in her all too short lived film career.

For the most part Sullivanâs Travels performs like an average mediocre comedy. Though it does have some memorable lines at the beginning, and a good enough premise carry a film, and Veronica Lake,  for the most part this movie really just seems to phoning it in. It isnât until the last 15 minutes it reaches something bigger then itself.
The first and final acts are beautifully done, but the rest was just too self-consciously witty.
This really surprised me. Just when it seems like everything is settled, a 4th act is conjured up and turns a decent comedy into something really unique.
Very revealing and somewhat bold movie about poverty (and Hollywood)
Satirical Preston Sturges gem with real time consequences. Great rom-com too. Love it and Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake (see her in I Married A Witch too).

One of the best romantic comedies ever.  Veronica Lake is adorable and Joel McCrea believeably earnest as a director of comedies who wants to make a great art film.  (Which he would call "Oh Brother Where Art Thou?").  Classic Preston Sturges.

nothing short of brilliant. tack-sharp comedy, rich satire, thought-provoking social commentary, effortless drama, intriguing plot twists, all carried out beautifully by the dry-witted McCrea, the adorably beautiful Lake, and the host of supporting cast.  a truly rock-solid film.

nothing short of brilliant. tack-sharp comedy, rich satire, thought-provoking social commentary, effortless drama, intriguing plot twists, all carried out beautifully by the dry-witted McCrea, the adorably beautiful Lake, and the host of supporting cast.  a truly rock-solid film.

The perfect picture business comedy. "There's a lot to be said for making people laugh. Did you know that that's all some people have? It isn't much, but it's better than nothing in this cockeyed caravan." Genius.
And then he fell through a hole and sneezed at a horse!

Amazing. Challenging. YOU must watch this.
It always reminds me of how important comedy, and maybe, all entertainment is in life. A truly touching classic!

Scratch anything I've said before, Veronica Lake is THE poster girl for adorability. Preston Sturges sure knows how to pick his leading ladies. Very, very good satire with a solid message and well-timed transitions. I love films that show versatility.
Interesting at times funny movie about Hollywood's lack of authenticity...promotes a kind of hokey comedy as some sort of social salve
Pretty close to perfect.
Brilliant and funny in its own right, it's also a smart consideration of art and artists and audiences.
Makes me cray. Makes me fall in love. Makes me so proud to be a comedian. One of the greatest films of all time.

I watched this recently not knowing what to expect, and thoroughly enjoyed, although I;m not quite sure it's as good as some believe it is. A near great film about making movies, this is a great watch if your are feeling a bit down and need a good laugh.

Extremely funny with some social commentary. Great.
Well, drown my kittens; this is quite a film.

The staggeringly simplistic moralizing at the end almost ruins the perfect mix of both zaniness and sophisticated wordplay that precedes it. I loved that I had no idea where this movie was going even by the beginning of the third act.
Greatest movie about a movie ever?  Maybe.

I've seriously neglected older films in my RT journal so I'm trying to watch (or in many cases rewatch) a bunch of classics in a feeble attempt at a well-rounded journal!  Somehow I never managed to see a Preston Sturges film....until now.  
 
[b]Sullivan's Travels (1941) - 8.3/10[/b]
Director - Preston Sturges
Starring - Joel McCrea, Veronica Lake, William Demarest, Robert Warwick, Eric Blore, Robert Greig, Porter Hall.
 
[i]Sullivan's Travels[/i], set in the Depression era, stars Joel McCrea as Hollywood director John L. Sullivan.  Sullivan has made his mark in Hollywood directing profitable, yet lightweight comedies.  Fed up with an "out-of-touch" Hollywood, Sullivan decides he wants to make a socially conscience film entitled "O Brother, Where Art Thou" about poverty and human suffering.  His producers balk at this idea, but that only fuels Sullivan's desires more.  Since Sullivan has never experienced the human suffering he wishes to write about he decides to pose as a hobo and live among the "real" people of America.  His studio, realizing they can't talk him out of it decides to turn his journey into a publicity stunt, following him around everywhere he goes.  Sullivan tries to shake them and ends up at a cafe where he meets a struggling actress (Veronica Lake) who thinks he is a bum, not a Hollywood director.  She buys him lunch and decides to join him on his journey soon discovering his real identity.  The pair experiences life among the poor and then it's time to return to Hollywood.  Sullivan decides to make one last visit, this time to pass out hundreds of $5 dollar bills to the tramps he encountered.  Unfortunately he is mugged and left unconscious in a railyard.  The thief also steals Sullivan's identity and is run over by a train leading everyone to believe he is dead.  Meanwhile Sullivan, unable to prove his identity, is arrested for assault and sentenced to a chain gang.
 
My first experience with Sturges was definitely positive.  [i]Sullivan's Travels [/i]is easily one of the best comedies of it's era.  Sturges liberally uses elements of screwball, slapstick and drama, but at it's core it's a biting satire.  Nobody is immune, but his ultimate target isn't the tramps and hobos, it's Hollywood's elite and Sullivan himself.  What really elevates this above other comedies of it's era is the writing.  The dialogue is clever, witty and often quite insightful.  The early scene where Sullivan tries to convince his producers to fund "Oh Brother, Where Art Thou" is a classic example of Sturges' fine writing.   Just when you think it's headed for typical screwball territory, Sturges changes gears.  He pauses just long enough to show real human suffering, for example the scene where McCrea and Lake are stepping over bodies searching for a place to sleep, which adds a needed dramatic element to a film that mocks almost everything.  The result is a hilarious comedy with a social conscience and one of the finest satires of Hollywood ever made.  It's influence is apparent from the Coen Brothers to Robert Altman's "The Player".  A must see.

The first hour consists of a poorly constructed inciting incident with mediocre banter and terrible slapstick comedy. The protagonist, who is not so well acted by Joel McCrea, is an absolute douchebag, and I didn't give a damn what happened to him. Surely that was the intention of the film, but Sturges can't expect to hold my attention that way. Veronica Lake was the only saving grace for the majority of the film. She's beautiful, charming, and loveable. The major flaw of the film is that the message Sturges is trying to communicate doesn't come into focus until the third act. The movie just lolls around in pretentious yuppie land until the beautifully cinematic ending. Things take a turn for the dark as the protagonist unwillingly reaches the dismal low point he'd been trying to discover all along. It's a powerful, dramatic climax that delivers the final thrust into poignancy. There are some rather incredible shots and great supporting characters. A decent film with a wonderful message.
Really great film. The running commentary on some of the absurdity of Hollywood is great.
Sturges' masterpiece.  Moves effortlessly from madcap comedy to near tragedy without missing a beat.

With the presence now of movies that are all about 'making a difference' about a problem, this really is a classic that should be seen more. It does a great job, I think, of looking at how for large scale problems, making a movie about it doesn't help most of the people going through those problems, but that comedy, light and unserious as it is, still has the power to uplift people and at least give them a break from what they have to deal with. It also does a good job of mocking how people who've never faced any trouble are inept at trying to understand what trouble really is.
Not the best example of Sturges's genius witty dialogue, but probably his most meaningful film and one of the best reflections on Hollywood I've ever seen: There's always a girl in the picture.
Nothing you would usually see.  A good watch
Just a really good fun movie that still holds up.
There are a number of supposed "classics" that I cannot get into. This is not one of them. This is a truly great film.
Excellent film -- witty, smart, deep. Much more introspective than most movies of the '40s.
Funny, touching and Veronica Lake!  A Preston Sturges classic!
very interesting for its time...a film director looking for a challenge in his life and wanting to make the perfect film for the depression...very well done

I really liked this one. It rings so true with so many people I know.
Sullivan is a well know moving picture maker in LA and is wanting to make a movie- O' Brother Where Art Thou as a gritty realism picture of the pain of poor America.
So he convinces his studio to let him go undercover as a poor man as research. In the midst he is fed a meal by Veronica Lake whom he falls for (though he's in a marriage of convenience). He breaks his cover for her and they are off again trying to look poor.
They hit bump after bump and are always finding themselves back in posh LA (when the going gets rough).
On his last expedition a bum fight  leaves people thinking he's dead. When he gets in the tussle he has a head injury leading to short term amnesia and a fist-a-cuff with a rail manager. This gets him in working prison.
This is where he realizes the power of comedic movies for the poor, and no longer wants to make O' Brother Where Art Thou, but comedies.
(Later, the studios grump because he has so much press for his exploits)
He finally declares he's the murderer of himself and gets off free. His wife is already re-married allowing him to get with Veronica Lake.

great!

A comedy filled with puns, slapstick, irony and plain stupidity.  There's also a social commentary hidden in there somewhere, but you'd be too enticed in its story to notice.  Veronica Lake is beautiful, but why are women always so annoying in black and white films?
Well made & a little funny!

Like Wilder's "Ace in the Hole", Preston Sturges' career masterpiece mimics and reflects an important cultural issue so that it can be seen in all of its truth while still radiating enormous amounts of entertainment. A cast with lesser-known stars keeps things honest and modest, and a chilling finale in a church ties everything up perfectly. "With a little sex."

That such a deep and powerful commentary could be made under the guise of light and playful dialogue is intriguing. Director Preston Sturges deftly includes several different themes, all the while mainting a singular tone. One of the best and most seriously played romantic, screwball comedies ever made.
